channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: Free Lunch? Yes, Please. Perl job in Vienna.
item.description: One of the largest product and price comparison platforms in German-speaking countries is on the hunt for a Perl programmer who wants to use their skills to eradicate inflated prices. Client is willing to consider all candidates with strong Perl, but they make heavy use of PostgreSQL, Elasticsearch, and Dancer, any of which would be useful to have experience with.

item.title: Variety is the spice of life! Perl Developer role in Dubai!
item.description: Spice up your 9-to-5 in the playground of the rich and famous! The client is a financial company whose meteoric growth over the last twenty years means that they’re a solid investment for anyone looking to make a change in location for their career. A new, exciting life in one of the most dynamic international cities is only a click away, so what are you waiting for?

item.title: Frankenstein’s Monster is Just Misunderstood! Perl in Australia
item.description: Our client’s area of expertise is decidedly less icky than ol’ Frankenstein. Their unique software is used to provide genotyping information about crops, which in turn helps to develop new species of plants. Feeding the planet? Much better way to save the environment than repurposing a few arms and legs. They’re looking for a bright mind with modern Perl skills.

item.title: Just Another Day Working in Perl Paradise (Perl developer job in Malta)
item.description: Our client's Malta office is looking for Perl developers with a strong exposure to Modern Perl – you’ll be comfortable with Plack/PSGI, Moose, and writing tests. Surrounded by the dazzling turquoise waters of the Mediterranean Sea, Malta is known for its 300 days of sunshine, its comprehensive and incredibly inexpensive healthcare, its arts and culture, and the delectable cuisine.

item.title: Business Casual has a Whole New Meaning. Perl role in South Germany
item.description: Online shopping, socializing, working—it’s a digital world now, which is perfect for our client. As an international IT company managing millions of domains for retail and corporate customers in nearly every country in the world, they’re busier than ever—and they need a few senior Perl developers to help them continue to thrive.

item.title: German Perl Workshop 2021
item.description: It will be in Leipzig on March 24-26 2021. CFP is open.

item.title: Charlotte Perl Mongers - Using the ActiveState Platform
item.description: Wednesday, January 27, 2021; 6:00 PM EST

item.title: Houston Perl Mongers Online Meeting - Atomic Operations in Unix (and Perl).
item.description: January 14, 2021 06:00 PM Central Time (US and Canada)

item.title: Derrick Talks renv - Purdue Perl Mongers
item.description: Wednesday, January 13, 2021; 5:30 PM EST

item.title: New Perl Course: Parallel processing in Perl
item.description: I have started to record a new course on parallel programming in Perl. I still have plenty to add to the course, but I already wanted to let you know about it and I already wanted to give you access to it. In the coming days you can use the coupon code FORK1 to get 50% discount on the course price.

item.title: NICEPERL's lists
item.description:
Great modules released last week;
MetaCPAN weekly report;
StackOverflow Perl report.

item.title: A Complete Course of the Raku programming language
Advent of Code 2020 — Day 12 in Perl
Weekly Challenge 094
item.description: Simon made the Anagram Grouping task looks like school boy task. Incredible.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 94: Binary Anagrams
item.description: Roger blog is not just limited to Perl and Raku but also present bonus solution in Python, Ruby and Rust.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 94
item.description: Luis one-liner is very impressive. Must Read.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 94: I’M (nearly) BACK!
item.description: Welcome back Luca. It is so inspiring to see him back in action.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 94: Group Anagrams and Binary Tree to Linked List
item.description: Laurent yet another detailed descriptive blog for both Perl and Raku. Highly Recommended.

item.title: Perl weekly challenge 94
item.description: James short and precise blog for quick read.

item.title: Solving Perl Weekly Challenge 094 -- Group Anagrams and Binary Tree to Linked List
item.description: If you are looking for some Raku magic then don't forget to checkout Kang-min blog. It is never short of cool ideas.

item.title: PWC094 - Binary Tree to Linked List
item.description: Flavio showing the power of code reuse and proving the point, 'Dont reinvent the wheel'.

item.title: PWC094 - Group Anagrams
item.description: Flavio style of blogging is very interesting. Reading the blog kind of magic, keep you engaged.

item.title: Flattened Anagrams: Perl Weekly Challenge #94
item.description: Dave's blog is always inspiring and technical to keep you engaged. Must Read.

item.title: CY's Take on PWC#094
item.description: I like the fighting nature of Cheok-Yin. Don't give up, you are doing great.

item.title: Anagram Nut Clusters
item.description: Little late but worth the effort, thanks for sharing the blog. It is always fun and pleasure.

item.title: Binary Linked Anagrams with Raku
item.description: I look forward to Arne blog every week to see how creative it is going to be this time with regard to the blog title. Thanks for the yet another quality blog.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 094
item.description: Adam thanks for reminding the "Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic". It seems I no longer know any Mathematics.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 94
item.description: Aaron solution to the second task "Binary Tree to Linked List" is so well structured and organised. Cool Raku code.

item.title: Perl Review - The Weekly Challenge - 092
item.description: Perl Solutions Review by Colin Crain.

item.title: RECAP - The Weekly Challenge - 094
item.description: Enjoy a quick recap of last week's contributions by Team PWC dealing with the "Group Anagrams" and "Binary Tree to Linked List" tasks in Perl and Raku. You will find plenty of solutions to keep you busy.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge - 095
item.description: Welcome to a new week with couple of fun tasks "Palindrome Number" and "Demo Stack". If you are new to the weekly challenge then why not join us and have fun every week. For more information, please read FAQ page.

item.title: Not just another Perl form framework
item.description: Bartosz introducing his latest work, Form::Tiny.

item.title: New To Perl? What Do You Need?
item.description: Developers who use Perl are invited to take a survey to provide feedback on what help and guidance they would find useful. It's a Perl Foundation initiative to guide developers in their journey of learning Perl.

item.title: ABC Mart
item.description: Ben following the Mojolicious pattern of listing methods and functions in alphabetical order. Even tests are arranged alphabetically.

item.title: Coding in Perl? What support do you need?
Optimize GitHub Actions for Perl
item.description: If you use GitHub Actions for your CI/CD you know it doesn't treat Perl as a first class citizen. This tutorial-style post can help you learn how to deploy a prebuilt Perl environment into GitHub Actions, simplifying and speeding up your CI/CD.

item.title: #494 - Perl Myths
item.description:
Hi there

Welcome to my first edition of newsletter of year 2021. I hope you had great start so far.

Today I am going to share my personal experience from back 1999. It was the year when I was first introduced to Perl and joined startup building Perl developers team. In the team, we have 2 newcomers (incuding myself) and 1 senior dev. My first project was a web based app using MySQL as database. I had really hard time to install DBI on my dev box. The senior dev was reluctant to help me. I approached my manager and he told me to build the project against text file for time being. I was given Black & White monitor and expected to build the colorfull web app. Fast forward, the project completed with all the obstacles and it was time to demo. Guess what, I was given color monitor this time. As expected it didn't look professional and embarassed me. However few months later, I found out the help to install DBI.

Why am I sharing this story?

Well last week, a Perl enthusiast from Indonesia contacted me on Twitter having trouble installing Calendar::Hijri. I was wondering how did he know about my Twitter account as I didn't share the information in the pod. With little fight, the issue was resolved and he got the colorfull Hijri calendar. It is so satisfactory to be able to help fellow hacker.

Coding in Perl? What support do you need?

The Perl Foundation is running the survey. It is aimed to guide newcomers. There is on going discussion on the subject for you to checkout at Reddit

Have you come across any Perl myths?

I guess, yes. Someone who used Perl for years must have rebuked Perl myths. I recently came across an article titled Debunking Perl Myths by Pritesh Ugrankar. I feel so happy to see fellow Indian being discussed widely with regard to Perl. I would recommend the article to anyone starting Perl so he/she starts with solid base.

Let me ask you a question, can you list new features released with Perl v5.xx?

I have had to fight for this information during the peak when I was actively contributing to CPAN modules. With time, I built up the notes. I remember Dave Cross gave talk on the similar topic at the London Perl Workshop 2016. I had the honour to be in the room. I still remember, for the first time, I came to know about the special source code token "__SUB__" introduced in Perl v5.16. If you are keen to know the detailed discussion of each features with every release then I would recommend the latest creation of brian d foy, titled Perl new features v5.10 to v5.32. It is published by Dave Cross's Perl School. Whatever little I have read so far, it is promising. Every Perl devs should have it handy. Thanks brian d foy for the review copy.

A fellow member of Facebook group Perl Programmers shared the video of struggle of new Perl developer. I enjoyed watching his struggle to get the right answer. I am sure there will be something to learn from his experience.

Are you looking for fresh start in the year 2021?

It is a fact the demand for Perl developers are not as high as it used to be. However there is one guy, Pete Sergeant, who single handedly kept us upto date with every possible opportunities across the globe. Don't forget to checkout the opportunities at the end of the newsletter. Pete is not just a recruiter but he is an experienced Perl hacker. Don't believe me? Please checkout his MetaCPAN profile.

Last but not the least you take care of yourself and your loved ones. Please enjoy rest of the newsletter.
